title: London Marathon
text:
This data comes from Nicola Rennie’s LondonMarathon R Package contining two data sets scraped from Wikipedia on (1 November 2022) on London Marathon winners, and some general data.

library(ggplot2)
winners <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-04-25/winners.csv')
london_marathon <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-04-25/london_marathon.csv')

ggplot(data = london_marathon, aes(x=Year, y=Accepted)) +
  geom_point() + labs(title ="Number of Accepted Runners vs Year")

title: Ameya Teli
text: Welcome! My name is Ameya Teli and I am a student at Pomona College graduating in 2027. I plan on majoring in Mathematics on the statistic track with a minor in Data Science.

title: Premier League 2021-2022
text:
Analysis of Goals Scored by Home Teams for each month of the Premier League in 2021-2022.
This data comes from Premier League Match Data 2021-2022 from Evan Gower.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyverse)


soccer <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-04-04/soccer21-22.csv')

soccer

# A tibble: 380 × 22
   Date      HomeTeam AwayTeam  FTHG  FTAG FTR    HTHG  HTAG HTR   Referee    HS
   <chr>     <chr>    <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr>   <dbl>
 1 13/08/20… Brentfo… Arsenal      2     0 H         1     0 H     M Oliv…     8
 2 14/08/20… Man Uni… Leeds        5     1 H         1     0 H     P Tier…    16
 3 14/08/20… Burnley  Brighton     1     2 A         1     0 H     D Coote    14
 4 14/08/20… Chelsea  Crystal…     3     0 H         2     0 H     J Moss     13
 5 14/08/20… Everton  Southam…     3     1 H         0     1 A     A Madl…    14
 6 14/08/20… Leicest… Wolves       1     0 H         1     0 H     C Paws…     9
 7 14/08/20… Watford  Aston V…     3     2 H         2     0 H     M Dean     13
 8 14/08/20… Norwich  Liverpo…     0     3 A         0     1 A     A Marr…    14
 9 15/08/20… Newcast… West Ham     2     4 A         2     1 H     M Atki…    17
10 15/08/20… Tottenh… Man City     1     0 H         0     0 D     A Tayl…    13
# ℹ 370 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: AS <dbl>, HST <dbl>, AST <dbl>, HF <dbl>, AF <dbl>,
#   HC <dbl>, AC <dbl>, HY <dbl>, AY <dbl>, HR <dbl>, AR <dbl>

soccer_month <- soccer |>
  mutate(Month = format(as.Date(Date,format="%d/%m/%Y"),"%m"))

soccer_month

# A tibble: 380 × 23
   Date      HomeTeam AwayTeam  FTHG  FTAG FTR    HTHG  HTAG HTR   Referee    HS
   <chr>     <chr>    <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <chr>   <dbl>
 1 13/08/20… Brentfo… Arsenal      2     0 H         1     0 H     M Oliv…     8
 2 14/08/20… Man Uni… Leeds        5     1 H         1     0 H     P Tier…    16
 3 14/08/20… Burnley  Brighton     1     2 A         1     0 H     D Coote    14
 4 14/08/20… Chelsea  Crystal…     3     0 H         2     0 H     J Moss     13
 5 14/08/20… Everton  Southam…     3     1 H         0     1 A     A Madl…    14
 6 14/08/20… Leicest… Wolves       1     0 H         1     0 H     C Paws…     9
 7 14/08/20… Watford  Aston V…     3     2 H         2     0 H     M Dean     13
 8 14/08/20… Norwich  Liverpo…     0     3 A         0     1 A     A Marr…    14
 9 15/08/20… Newcast… West Ham     2     4 A         2     1 H     M Atki…    17
10 15/08/20… Tottenh… Man City     1     0 H         0     0 D     A Tayl…    13
# ℹ 370 more rows
# ℹ 12 more variables: AS <dbl>, HST <dbl>, AST <dbl>, HF <dbl>, AF <dbl>,
#   HC <dbl>, AC <dbl>, HY <dbl>, AY <dbl>, HR <dbl>, AR <dbl>, Month <chr>

soccer_grouped <- soccer_month |>
  group_by(Month) |>
  summarize(Total_Goals = sum(FTHG)) 

soccer_grouped <- mutate(soccer_grouped, Month_Name = month.name[as.numeric(Month)])

soccer_grouped |>
  ggplot(aes(x=Month_Name, y=Total_Goals)) + 
    geom_bar(stat="identity") +
    labs(title = "Goals Scored by Home Teams", x= "Month", y = "Goals by Home Team") +
  scale_x_discrete(expand = expansion(add = 0.5)) + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust = 1, hjust = 1))

title: Project
text:
Link to Database

library(ggplot2)
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2023-12-12')

holiday_movies <- tuesdata$holiday_movies
holiday_movie_genres <- tuesdata$holiday_movie_genres

holiday_movie_genres

holiday_movies

First Plot - What genre do movies with love in the title fall under?

library(stringr)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

colnames(holiday_movies)

 [1] "tconst"          "title_type"      "primary_title"   "original_title" 
 [5] "year"            "runtime_minutes" "genres"          "simple_title"   
 [9] "average_rating"  "num_votes"       "christmas"       "hanukkah"       
[13] "kwanzaa"         "holiday"        

#holiday_movies$simple_title

love <- holiday_movies|>
  filter(str_detect(simple_title, "love"))
love

# A tibble: 32 × 14

   <chr>    <chr>      <chr>         <chr>          <dbl>           <dbl> <chr>

 2 tt00855… tvMovie    The Gift of … The Gift of L…  1983              96 Drama 
 3 tt00999… tvMovie    The Kid Who … The Kid Who L…  1990             118 Drama 
 4 tt01370… tvMovie    A Holiday fo… Christmas in …  1996             105 Drama…
 5 tt04142… tvMovie    Love Hina Ch… Rabu Hina kur…  2000              46 Anima…

love_genre <- love|>
  mutate(genre_list = genres)|>
  separate(genres, c('first','second', 'third'))
love_genre

This plot shows that the most prevalent genre’s for holiday movies about love are Romance, Family, Drama, and Comedy.
2nd Plot - Genres of Holiday Movies

ggplot(holiday_movie_genres, aes(x = genres)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Genres of Holiday Movies", x = "Genre") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








3rd Plot -

title: Shakespeare Textual Analysis
text:
This my textual analysis of Shakespeare dialogue in his tragedy “Romeo and Juliet”.
This data was curated by Nicola Rennie from The Complete Works of William Shakespeare the Web’s first edition of the Complete Works of William Shakespeare.

hamlet <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-09-17/hamlet.csv')
macbeth <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-09-17/macbeth.csv')
romeo_juliet <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-09-17/romeo_juliet.csv')

How much is death mentioned in Romeo and Juliet?

library(stringr)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

deathrj <- romeo_juliet |>
 filter(str_detect(dialogue, "death")) 
  

ggplot(deathrj, aes(x = character)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Which character mentions death the most?", x = "Character") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) 







library(stringr)

act_num <- deathrj |>
  mutate(act = str_extract(act, "(?<=\\s)\\S+"))  
  
ggplot(act_num, aes(x = act)) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Which act has most mentions of death?", x = "Act") 








This first graph shows that Romeo has the most instances of the word “death” in his dialogue and Friar Laurence had the second most in his dialogue. This is interesting because it makes sense that Romeo says death the most as he eventually is one of those who die in this tragedy and Friar Laurence is the one to encourage this from selling a sleeping potion. As Romeo has more dialogue presumably as one of the more main characters it makes sense that he has more mentions by count versus the Apothecary who sells Romeo poison that will kill him.
Romeo and Juliet die in Act 5 Scene 3, so having the most mentions of death in Act 3 is interesting. Maybe there is some foreshadowing happening here or something else significant which we can look through in the next plot.
This plot will analyze specifically dialogue in Act 3 looking for exclamations and question marks which indicate a strong emotion in the dialogue.

filtered_act_num <- act_num |>
  filter(act == "III")|>
  mutate(strong_punctuation = str_detect(dialogue, "!+|\\?+")) |>
  mutate(scene = str_extract(scene, "(?<=\\s)\\S+"))  
  

ggplot(filtered_act_num, aes(x = scene, fill = strong_punctuation))+
  geom_bar(position = "fill") + 
  labs(title = "Proportion of strong punctuation marks across scenes", x = "Scene", y = "Proportion")








This shows that there is a greater proportion of strong punctuation in Scene 5 than the rest. So potentially the strongest emotions in relation to death occur here? We will also check which scene had the most mentions of death below.

ggplot(filtered_act_num, aes(x = scene)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Mentions of death across scenes in Act III", x = "Scene", y = "Count")








Maybe this indicates that the mentions of death in the other scenes are less emotional and thus use less strong punctuation. We will look for the following word, symbol, or space after death, to see how they compare.

filtered_act_num <- act_num |>
  filter(act == "III")|>
  mutate(word_after_death = str_extract(dialogue, "death\\s*\\S+"))

ggplot(filtered_act_num, aes(x = word_after_death))+
  geom_bar(stat = "count")+
  labs(title = "Death and the Word/Character after in Act III", 
       x = "Death + Word", 
       y = "Count")+
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








The most common thing following death is a comma, indicating that death ends a thought of most of the dialogue in Act III. This is interesting if we wanted to analyze the style that Shakespeare uses to foreshadow the impending doom of Romeo and Juliet and those others who face tragic endings.

filtered_act_num

# A tibble: 25 × 6
   act   scene     character      dialogue          line_number word_after_death
   <chr> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>                   <dbl> <chr>           
 1 III   Scene I   Mercutio       cat, to scratch …        1525 death!          
 2 III   Scene I   Benvolio       Stand not amazed…        1560 death,          
 3 III   Scene I   Benvolio       Cold death aside…        1590 death aside,    
 4 III   Scene II  Juliet         Than the death-d…        1676 death-darting   
 5 III   Scene II  Juliet         Some word there …        1739 death,          
 6 III   Scene II  Juliet         Hath slain ten t…        1745 <NA>            
 7 III   Scene II  Juliet         But with a rear-…        1752 death,          
 8 III   Scene II  Juliet         In that word's d…        1757 death;          
 9 III   Scene II  Juliet         And death, not R…        1768 death,          
10 III   Scene III Friar Laurence Not body's death…        1786 death,          
# ℹ 15 more rows


Upon viewing the first few lines of this data frame we can see that “Tybalt’s death” is mentioned a great amount, so perhaps the reason death is mentioned so much in this Act is because this character actually did die.


Future analysis on how family names associate with mentions of death:
These next two plots analyze which characters mention the Montague’s and the Capulet’s the most - the two rivaling families within Romeo and Juliet.

romeo_juliet |>
  mutate(dialogue_lower = str_to_lower(dialogue))|>
  filter(str_detect(dialogue_lower, "montague")) |>
  filter(character != "[stage direction]") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = character)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Which character mentions the Montague family the most?", x = "Character") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) 







romeo_juliet |>
  mutate(dialogue_lower = str_to_lower(dialogue))|>
  filter(str_detect(dialogue_lower, "capulet")) |>
  filter(character != "[stage direction]") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = character)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "count") + 
  labs(title = "Which character mentions the Capulet family the most?", x = "Character") + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) 








These two plots show that Juliet mentions the Montague family the most and Benvolio, Prince, and Romeo mention the Capulet family the most. This is interesting because Romeo and Juliet have the most dialogue presumably as they are main characters so they mention the family names the most.

title: Permutation Test
text:
Source: openintro package R/data-sex_discrimination.R
Objective: See if there is a correlation between gender and being promoted from a study in the 1970s about bank manager recommendations based on sex. We want to show that the proportion of women who are promoted is less than men and that this is significant.
Our null hypothesis is that gender does not affect the likelihood that men or women are promoted.

library(openintro)


sex_discrimination

# A tibble: 48 × 2
   sex   decision
   <fct> <fct>   
 1 male  promoted
 2 male  promoted
 3 male  promoted
 4 male  promoted
 5 male  promoted
 6 male  promoted
 7 male  promoted
 8 male  promoted
 9 male  promoted
10 male  promoted
# ℹ 38 more rows


The following code is to calculate the summary statistic for our data.

library(dplyr)
#the number of males and females in the study
nmale = sum(sex_discrimination$sex == "male")
nfemale = sum(sex_discrimination$sex =="female")

#the number of males and females that were promoted

males <- filter(sex_discrimination, sex == "male")

male_promoted = sum(males$decision == "promoted")

females <- filter(sex_discrimination, sex == "female")

female_promoted = sum(females$decision == "promoted")

#calculating the proportion of promotion with regard to gender 

prop_male <- male_promoted/nmale

prop_female <- female_promoted/nfemale

#create a dataframe with these summary statistics

gender_data <- data_frame(
  Gender = c("male", "female"), 
  Count = c(nmale, nfemale),
  Promoted = c(male_promoted, female_promoted), 
  Proportion = c(prop_male, prop_female)
)

gender_data

# A tibble: 2 × 4
  Gender Count Promoted Proportion
  <chr>  <int>    <int>      <dbl>
1 male      24       21      0.875
2 female    24       14      0.583

#Calculating the different between the proportion of males that were promoted and females that were promoted
obs_diff <- prop_male - prop_female
obs_diff

[1] 0.2916667


Now we generate a null sampling distribution

library(dplyr)
library(purrr)

#function to find the proportion of a specific gender which are given a promotion 

find_prop <- function(gender, data, promote_col){
  gender_specific <- filter(data, sex == gender)
  n_gender <- sum(data$sex == gender)
  gender_promoted <- sum(gender_specific[[promote_col]] == "promoted" )
  return(gender_promoted/n_gender)
}

#test that find_prop works 
find_prop("male", sex_discrimination, "decision")

[1] 0.875

#we care about whether or not females are promoted the same as or less than the males so we care about the sign of the difference (hence no absolute value)
find_prop_diff <- function(data, promote_col){
  find_prop("male", data, promote_col) - find_prop("female", data, promote_col)
}

find_prop_diff(sex_discrimination, "decision")

[1] 0.2916667

#function to permute the data & calculate the the proportion difference 
perm_data <- function(data){
  data <- data |>
    mutate(promote_perm = sample(decision, replace = FALSE)) 
  summarize(data, obs_prop_diff = find_prop_diff(data, "promote_perm"))
}


library(ggplot2)

#mapping the permutation 
replication <- function(rep, data){
  map_dfr(1:rep, ~perm_data(data))
}

set.seed(4747)
perm_stats <- replication(100, sex_discrimination)

ggplot(perm_stats, aes(x = obs_prop_diff)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth = .05) + 
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = obs_diff), color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Null Distribution of Promotion Differences by Gender", 
       x = "Proportion Difference (Permuted Data)",
       y = "Frequency") + 
  theme_minimal()








This is a graph of the null sampling distribution, that is we permuted the data many times switching the labels for men and women and promoted vs. not promoted and plotted this on the above histogram. The red vertical line shows our observed difference from the initial the sex_discrimination data from the study.

sum(perm_stats>=obs_diff)

[1] 2


There are only two entries from our null sampling distribution that are greater than or equal to our observed difference from the sampling distribution. This gives us a p value of 0.02 which is very small. Small enough for us to reject our null hypothesis. Thus the gender of the person does make a difference on whether or not they were promoted. More specifically to the point of this simulation study, the proportion of females promoted was significantly fewer than the proportion of men who were promoted. Thus gender, specifically being a female plays a significant role.
